properties.name: Baylor University Medical Center at Dallas
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler  3500 Gaston Ave, Dallas, TXThe building has changed some since then, but this is where it all started for me back on November 17, 1960. I was born to Archie and Willena Lambert, an electrical Engineer with an MS, working at TI. and his wife who\'d been married since January of that same year. I was the first of four children. We lived in Garland, north of Dallas and near Texas Instruments.

properties.name: Col. John B. Wyman Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler In late 1968 we moved to Rolla, Missouri. Dad left TI to advance his education. He accepted a fellowship to teach Engineering while working on his PhD at the University of Missouri at Rolla, the old Missouri School of Mines, or UMR. I started second grade (finally!) at Col John B. Wyman Elementary school. Mrs. Patterson was my teacher. I never knew who Col. John B. Wyman was or why they named the school after him. I still don\'t, but I do know what he looked like. When you search his name online you get lots of references to the school in Rolla that bears his name, but no information about him. Here is his picture for those who are curious. He was a cival war Col. from Illinois, and led infantry. I am really sorry I cannot tell you more...dunno much about history...

properties.name: Edith Landels Elementry School
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler  115 West Dana Street Mountain View, CA 94041 650.526.3520 Fax 650.969.7036 Principal: Carmen Mizell cmizell@mvwsd.org Secretary: Barbara Dolan bdolan@mvwsd.org Office Assistant: Diane Rygiol drygiol@mvwsd.org Community Liason Worker: Alma Estiva aestiva@mvwsd.org Edith Landels was my first school. In 1965-66 Mr Stratton was the principal, and Mrs. Gardiner was my kindergarten teacher. There were 29 students in the class and there was no such thing as Ritlin, Concerta, or Abilify. Here are pictures of my kindergarten class , the teacher, principal, and the school building.

properties.name: First Home in Rolla
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler As you can see if you are using the satelite view, there is no house on this site now. I can testify that that was not always the case. In late 1967 this was the site of our home. The house was old even then, a frame building with a coal oil heater in the basement, and drafty rooms throughout. Just next to our home (in the space south of the marker pin, in what looks like a parking lot) was the home of our neighbors who had real names although they cannot be remembered because my brother and sister and I all just called them Mrs. Long Hair and Mr Beard. I thought of them as our hippy neighbors. For those of you who remember, on Halloween that year, I went trick or treating as the Frito Bandito. The Highschool was just up the block and around the corner, I assume that the largish building I see East and North of our old home site is the Highschool today. When I was in second grade I attended a presentation of Androcles and the Lion, a play by George Bernard Shaw at the Highschool auditorium.

properties.name: Home from 1967 through 1968
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler Our Home in \'67 and \'68 was on Summit Drive in Richardson, Texas. Dad had accepted an offer to return to Texas Instruments as head of a research and design team. TI was on the cutting edge in the electronics industry and dad was on the team that designed the first micro processors and integrated circuits.

properties.name: Lake Marie and The Snowy Range
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler

properties.name: Lammars Hall @ Westfield State College
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler   Lammars Hall is one of the dormatories on the Westfield State College Campus The photo shows the ELY Center, Library Bookstore and Center of Campus life. In the early 1980\'s the building had a bar called "The Owl\'s Nest " in the basement. The upperclassmen who were served there just called it "The Rat"

properties.name: Libby Lake and the Snowy Range
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler  Libby Lake is at the trailhead for Medicine Bow Peak, the High Point in the Snowy Range.

properties.name: Maramec Spring Park
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler    Our stay in Missouri, was seasoned with lots of time outdoors. Camping, canoing, picnicing, and hiking were some of the diversions our family would enjoy. Maramec Spring was one of our favorite spots for cookouts and meandering. It was close enough that we wouldn\'t have to spend the whole day getting there. It is the site of an old Iron Works from the early 1800\'s, and a trout hatchery that still is in operation. On our way home from visiting friends in Chicago in July of 2008, we stopped at Maramec so I could share it with my wife. It is just as I remember it from 40 years ago. The unique blue shade of the water is still as magical and mysterious as when I was 8 years old.

properties.name: Mariano Castro School
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler Mariano Castro Elementary School 505 Escuela Avenue Mountain View, CA 94040 Tel: 650-526-3590 Fax: 650-964-9013 Principal: Dr. Judy Crates jcrates@mvwsd.org Secretary: Mrs. Lanita Villasenor lvillasenor@mvwsd.org Office Clerk: Ms. Susie Jaramillo sjaramillo@mvwsd.org Mariano Castro School looks somewhat different today than it did back in \'66 when Mr. Mauntz was the principal and Mrs. Baker was my first grade teacher, but then I look a bit different now too.

properties.name: Mark Twain Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler 681 Salem Ave, Rolla, MOWe moved after 3rd grade, I think it was shame, we needed a new locale where people didn\'t know that "their oldest son flunked out of third grade arithmetic" so we moved to Rose Court, in the old Rolla Gardens subdivision, and I got a new school, Mark Twain Elementary. I attended 4th and 5th grade here, the only memory I have of 4th grade is music class, I had to scratch my head HARD to remember my 4th grade teacher, Mrs. Hood. The principal was Mr Opperman. Fifth grade was better, my teacher was Mrs. Repond, and she lived in Rolla Gardens on my new (second) paper route. I also delivered the Green Acres route, but only for the last 9 months of our time in Rolla.

properties.name: Mdeicine Bow Peak Trail Between Sugarloaf and Medicine Bow Peak
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler  About midway from libby Lake trailhead to the summit of Medicine Bow Peak. Between Sugarloaf mountain and Medicine Bow Peak. First and third photos looking toward the Snowy Range (SW) second photo toward Libby Lake, and last photo toward Sugarloaf.

properties.name: Medicine Bow Peak
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler  View from the Summit of Medicine Bow Peak.

properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler

properties.name: Nash Fork Campground
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler   US Forest Service Campground in the Medicine Bow National Forest.

properties.name: Rolla Daily News
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler I was 8. I wanted a job. WHAT WAS I THINKING? My first job was as a newsboy for the Rolla Daily News. I picked up my papers daily at the circulation office, and deliverd my route. I had around 60 customers, and a Daily paper was a nickle, the Sunday paper was ten cents.I got to keep 3 cents of every paper I sold. Around the corner on the 600 Block of Elm was a liquor store where I\'d go with the older carriers and buy Beer-nuts, Bugles, and Grape-ette soda. Across from the liquor store and separated from the newspaper circulation office by the railroad tracks was the Purina Dogfood Mill.

properties.name: Second House in Rolla
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler Adrian street was the site of our second Home in Rolla. It was also on my first newspaper route. We lived here when I was in the third grade, at Col. John B.Wyman Elementary. My teacher in 3rd Grade was Mrs. Deacock, she was Satan\'s sister. Every day of third grade she would send me home with a note pinned to my shirt, usually I think the note said something like "your son needs a sound spanking", or "have you whipped your child today?" These notes were a constant source of enjoyment for me as a child and strengthened my realtionship with my family in so many ways. I failed third grade arithmetic, God bless Mrs. Deacock. Her husband it seems, Dr. Deacock, (Phd, not MD) was one of my father\'s professors. I don\'t think dad liked him anymore than I liked her, but he sure didn\'t like him asking about the prodigy child that dad had at home. My brother was now in second grade and bringing home all top marks. Third grade sucked.

properties.name: Terrace Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler Richardson Terrace Elementary 300 N. Dorothy Avenue, Richardson, Texas 75081 Phone: (469) 593-8700 Fax: 469-593-8780 Principal: Sharon Newman Assistant Principal(s): Jenny Lanier When we moved back to Texas in 1967, this is where I went to school. I wasn\'t as bright as the kids going into the second grade, and was younger than most of them, so my folks talked with the teachers and principal and decided it would be best for me to enjoy the first grade again. What fun! I guess they were right to do so. I remember Terrace Elementary as the school where I learned about two of the three states of matter. The cafeteria had a freezer and frequently after lunch I would buy an ice cream bar. One day I got the bright idea that I\'d save the frozen fudge bar I bought to eat on my way home from school, so I put it in my locker after lunch and went back to class. When I got out of class later that day I learned what happens to solids when they get too hot. There was liquid fudge syrup all over everything in my locker and an empty wrapper and a popsicle stick. No second grader would have made a blunder like that. Second Grade students had already been introduced to Elementary Physics and Introductory Thermodynamics. Needless to say, my dad the Advanced Degree Electrical Engineer, and Project Team Leader at TI was more than a tad concerned about my lack of grasp. I spent that summer doing arithmatic workbooks while my friends played outside.

properties.name: Third and Final Home in Rolla
properties.description: Posted by Mountaincrawler 66 Rose Court was the third house we lived in in Rolla. The house still stands in Rolla Gardens, a tiny crackerbox of a house in a subdivision of crackerbox houses. It was our home for my fourth and fifth Grade years. It\'s where we lived when Armstrog walked on the moon. It\'s where we lived when I burned my middle finger of my left hand on marshmallow.
